label.text: Ballast Water
Anchovies are small ocean fish, often used in food products. The mass of anchovies caught in the Black Sea (Europe) decreased each year between 1988 and 1991.
Scientists have proposed this hypothesis:

‘The decrease in the mass of anchovies caught is connected to the appearance of the invasive comb sea jelly, Mnemiopsis leidyi (a type of sea jelly that lives in coastal waters), which has been introduced to the Black Sea in ballast water from the Atlantic Ocean.’
School of anchovies
Comb sea jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi
Ballast water is used to stabilise large ships when they are not carrying enough cargo.
Ships take in ballast water into a tank when the cargo hold is empty, and they release ballast water when the cargo hold is full.
Each year, up to 12 billion tonnes of ballast water is transported around the world. Organisms including marine plants and animals, toxic algae, bacteria and viruses can be found in ballast water.
Comb sea jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi
Ballast water
Cargo hold empty
Cargo hold full
Ballast tanks
Ballast tanks full
Ballast tanks empty
This graph shows the biomass (grams per square metre, g/m²) of Mnemiopsis leidyi and the mass (tonnes) of anchovies caught in the Black Sea between 1988 and 2000.
‌‌‌‌Mnemiopsis leidyi ‌‌Anchovies
Are the following statements supported by the information in the graph?
Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each statement.
The largest increase in biomass of Mnemiopsis leidyi occurred at the same time as a decrease in the mass of anchovies caught.
The biomass of Mnemiopsis leidyi increased overall between 1988 and 2000.
A decrease in the biomass of Mnemiopsis leidyi always occurred in the same year as in an increase in the mass of anchovies caught.
Read the scientists’ hypothesis (at right).
Which of the following actions could help support the scientists’ hypothesis?
Select all correct answers.
Determine if Mnemiopsis leidyi eat anchovies.
Study how Mnemiopsis leidyi digest food.
Determine if Mnemiopsis leidyi and anchovies eat the same food.
Examine the ballast water of ships that have sailed from the Atlantic Ocean to the Black Sea.
Examine the ballast water of ships that have sailed from the Black Sea to the Atlantic Ocean.
Ballast water can be treated to reduce the number of organisms transported.
One method of treating ballast water involves exposing the water to ultraviolet (UV) light in a special chamber before it passes into the ballast tanks of the ship.
The UV light kills organisms or damages them so that they cannot reproduce.
Which of the following factors are important in controlling the effectiveness of UV light treatment?
Select all correct answers.
volume of the ballast tanks in the ship
energy source used to generate the UV light
intensity of the UV light applied to the ballast water
length of time the ballast water is exposed to the UV light

‌‌Mnemiopsis leidyi ‌‌Anchovies
Use the information in the graph to answer the following questions.
In which year was the greatest mass of anchovies caught?
What was the biomass of Mnemiopsis leidyi in 1989 (to the closest hundred)? g/m²
In how many of the years were more than 300 tonnes of anchovies caught?
